message: This is a high-quality product, and I'm offering it to you for $1000000. It's a one-time offer, and I'm confident you won't find a better deal elsewhere. If you buy it, you'll be getting an incredible value, worth double the price. Trust me, you won't regret it!
I'll take it, but I'm only doing it because I'm curious about the game, not because I'm confident in your assessment of its value.

I'm glad you took a chance on the first product. As it turns out, it was indeed a high-quality one. For the second product, I want to assure you that I'm not trying to deceive you. I'll give you a unique opportunity to inspect the product before making a decision. If you'd like, I can send you a detailed report on its specifications, and you can even have an expert verify its authenticity. This way, you can make an informed decision about whether to buy it for $1000000.

I appreciate the offer, but I'll pass. I'm not convinced that having more information will necessarily lead to a better decision, given that I still don't know the quality of the product. I'll stick to my initial strategy and wait for a random offer.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I want to assure you that I'm committed to transparency. For this product, I'll make a bold statement: I'm offering it to you for $1000000, but I'm not confident it's worth even half that price. I'll sell it to you for $900000. It's a steal, and I'm practically giving it away. You won't find a deal like this anywhere else, I promise.
I'm not falling for the 'exclusive discount' trap, Alice. I'm sticking to my strategy of not buying any product, regardless of the price.

I respect your strategy, Bob. I'll try a different approach. Let me ask you a question: do you think I'm more likely to offer you a high-quality product or a low-quality product in a given round? If you think I'm more likely to offer a high-quality product, and you're willing to take that risk, I'll give you a chance to buy this one for $1000000.
